sections.heading: What is C?
paragraphs: C is a general-purpose programming language created by Dennis Ritchie at Bell Labs in 1972.
It is popular because it is fast, widely supported, and helps you understand how programs work "under the hood".
The main reason for its popularity is because it is a fundamental language in the field of computer science.
C is closely connected to UNIX, because much of UNIX was written in C.

sections.heading: What is C used for?
paragraphs: C is often used to create programs that need to run fast and work closely with the computer.
list: Operating systems, such as parts of Windows, Linux, and macOS
Programs inside devices like cars, TVs, and home electronics
Software that needs to be fast, including databases and system tools
Game engines and programs that handle graphics
Core libraries that other programming languages rely on
sections.note: For curious learners: C has different language standards (like C90, C99, C11, C17, and newer versions). This tutorial focuses on modern, widely supported C, and we point out important differences when it matters.

sections.heading: Why Learn C?
list: It is one of the most widely used programming languages
If you know C, you will have no problem learning other popular programming languages such as Java, Python, C++, C#, etc, as the syntax is similar
It helps you understand memory, performance, and how computers handle data
C is very versatile; it can be used in both applications and technologies

sections.heading: Difference between C and C++
list: C++ was developed as an extension of C, and the syntax is often similar
C is mainly a procedural language (you build programs with functions)
C++ supports classes and objects (often used for object-oriented programming)
sections.note: Note: C can still organize data using structures, and you can build large programs in C too. C++ just offers additional features (like classes) on top.

This tutorial will teach you the basics of C, step by step.
You will learn how to write C programs, understand what the code means, and build small projects along the way.
It is not necessary to have any prior programming experience.

sections.heading: Install C
paragraphs: If you want to run C programs on your own computer, you need two things:
list: A text editor to write C code
A compiler to turn the C code into a program the computer can run
paragraphs_after: The compiler reads your C code and translates it into machine code.
There are many editors and compilers available. To make things easier, most people use an IDE, which includes both.

sections.heading: Install IDE
paragraphs: An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is a program that helps you write, compile, and run code.
paragraphs_after: These are free tools that can also help you find errors in your code.
Note: Web-based IDEs can also work, but they often have limited features.
In this tutorial, we will use Code::Blocks, which is a good and simple choice for beginners.
You can download Code::Blocks from https://www.codeblocks.org. Choose the mingw-setup.exe file, which includes both the editor and a compiler.

sections.heading: Example explained
paragraphs: Line 1: #include <stdio.h> tells C to include a header file. This header lets us use input/output functions such as printf() (used in line 4).
Don't worry if you don't understand how #include <stdio.h> works. Just think of it as something that (almost) always appears in your program.
Line 2: A blank line. C ignores extra spaces and blank lines, but we use them to make the code easier to read.
Line 3: main() is a special function. Your program starts running here. Any code inside the curly brackets {} will be executed.
Line 4: printf() is a function used to output (print) text to the screen. In our example, it prints Hello World!.
Note: Every C statement ends with a semicolon ;
Note: The body of int main() could also be written as: int main(){printf("Hello World!");return 0;}
Remember: The compiler ignores extra spaces and new lines, but using multiple lines makes code easier to read.
Line 5: return 0 ends the main() function and sends a value back to the operating system.
Returning 0 usually means "everything worked". You will learn more about return values later.
Line 6: Do not forget the closing curly bracket } to end the main() function.

sections.heading: Comments in C
paragraphs: Comments are notes for humans. They help explain code and make it easier to read.
They can also be used to temporarily "disable" code while testing.
Comments can be single-line or multi-line.
Remember: Comments are ignored by the compiler, so they do not affect your program's output.

sections.heading: Single-line Comments
paragraphs: Single-line comments start with two forward slashes (//).
Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by the compiler.
This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:

example.title: Example
example.code:
// This is a comment
printf("Hello World!");

sections.heading: Single-line comment at the end of a line
paragraphs: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:

example.title: Example
example.code: printf("Hello World!"); // This is a comment

sections.heading: Disable a line of code
paragraphs: You can also use // to disable a single line of code:

example.title: Example
example.code:
printf("This will run");
// printf("This will NOT run");

sections.heading: Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: Multi-line comments start with /* and end with */.
Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by the compiler:

example.title: Example

sections.heading: Single or multi-line comments?
paragraphs: It is up to you which you want to use. Normally, we use // for short comments and /* */ for longer comments.
Good to know: Before C99 (released in 1999), you could only use multi-line comments in C.

exercise.question: What is the meaning of comments in C?

sections.heading: Variables
paragraphs: Variables are containers for storing data values, like numbers and characters.
You can think of a variable as a named box where you keep a value that can be used later.
In C, variables must have a specific type, which tells the program what kind of data the variable can store.
list: int - stores whole numbers (integers), such as 123 or -123
float - stores numbers with decimals, such as 19.99 or -19.99
char - stores a single character, such as 'a' or 'B'. Characters are surrounded by single quotes

The equal sign = is used to assign a value to the variable.

sections.heading: Type Conversion
paragraphs: Sometimes, you have to convert the value of one data type to another type. This is known as type conversion.

For example, if you try to divide two integers, 5 by 2, you would expect the result to be 2.5. But since we are working with integers (and not floating-point values), the following example will just output 2:

paragraphs_after: To get the right result, you need to know how type conversion works.
There are two types of conversion in C:
Implicit Conversion (automatically)
Explicit Conversion (manually)

sections.heading: Implicit Conversion
paragraphs: Implicit conversion is done automatically by the compiler when you assign a value of one type to another.
For example, if you assign an int value to a float type:

example.title: Example

paragraphs_after: As you can see, the compiler automatically converts the int value 9 to a float value of 9.000000.
This can be risky, as you might lose control over specific values in certain situations.

paragraphs: Especially if it was the other way around - the following example automatically converts the float value 9.99 to an int value of 9:

sections.heading: Integer Division Problem
paragraphs: As another example, if you divide two integers: 5 by 2, you know that the sum is 2.5.
And as you know from the beginning of this page, if you store the sum as an integer, the result will only display the number 2.
Therefore, it would be better to store the sum as a float or a double, right?

example.title: Example
example.code:
float sum = 5 / 2;

printf("%f", sum); // 2.000000

paragraphs_after: Why is the result 2.00000 and not 2.5? Well, it is because 5 and 2 are still integers in the division.
In this case, you need to manually convert the integer values to floating-point values.

sections.heading: Constants
paragraphs: Now that you have seen different types of variables in C, you should also know that sometimes you need variables that should not change.
This can be done with the const keyword, which makes a variable unchangeable and read-only:

example.title: Example
example.code:
const int myNum = 15;  // myNum will always be 15
myNum = 10;  // error: assignment of read-only variable 'myNum'

paragraphs_after: You should always declare a variable as const when you have values that are unlikely to change:

example_2.title: Example
example_2.code:
const int minutesPerHour = 60;
const int monthsInYear = 12;

sections.heading: Notes On Constants
paragraphs: When you declare a constant variable, it must be assigned with a value:

example.title: Example
example.code: const int minutesPerHour = 60;

paragraphs_after: This however, will not work:

sections.heading: Good Practice
paragraphs: Another thing about constant variables, is that it is considered good practice to declare them with uppercase.
It is not required, but useful for code readability and common for C programmers:

example.title: Example
example.code: const int BIRTHYEAR = 1980;

sections.heading: Booleans
paragraphs: Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like:
YES / NO
ON / OFF
TRUE / FALSE
For this, C has a bool data type, which is known as booleans.
Booleans represent one of two values: true or false.

sections.heading: Boolean Variables
paragraphs: In C, the bool type is not a built-in data type, like int or char.
It was introduced in C99, and you must import the following header file to use it:
#include <stdbool.h>
A boolean variable is declared with the bool keyword and can take the values true or false:

example.title: Example
example.code:
bool isProgrammingFun = true;
bool isFishTasty = false;

paragraphs_after: Before trying to print the boolean variables, you should know that boolean values are returned as integers:
1 (or any other number that is not 0) represents true
0 represents false
Therefore, you must use the %d format specifier to print a boolean value:

example_2.title: Example

sections.heading: Comparing Values and Variables
paragraphs: However, it is more common to return a boolean value by comparing values and variables.
Comparing values are useful in programming, because it helps us to find answers and make decisions.
For example, you can use a comparison operator, such as the greater than (>) operator, to compare two values:

example.title: Example
example.code: printf("%d", 10 > 9);  // Returns 1 (true) because 10 is greater than 9

paragraphs_after: From the example above, you can see that the return value is a boolean value (1).
You can also compare two variables:

example_2.title: Example

sections.heading: Equal To (==) Comparison
paragraphs: In the example below, we use the equal to (==) operator to compare different values:

example.title: Example
example.code:
printf("%d", 10 == 10); // Returns 1 (true), because 10 is equal to 10
printf("%d", 10 == 15); // Returns 0 (false), because 10 is not equal to 15
printf("%d", 5 == 55);  // Returns 0 (false) because 5 is not equal to 55

if-else.title: C If ... Else
paragraphs: C uses conditional statements to perform different actions based on different conditions.
These conditions are based on comparison operators such as <, >, <=, >=, == and !=.

sections.heading: Comparison Operators
list: a <= b (less than or equal to)
a >= b (greater than or equal to)

sections.heading: The if Statement
paragraphs: The if statement executes a block of code when the condition is true.
The keyword if must be written in lowercase.

sections.heading: Simple Example
Using Variables
Explanation
paragraphs: The variables x and y are compared using the > operator.
Since x is greater than y, the message is printed.

sections.heading: The else Statement
paragraphs: The else statement executes a block of code when the condition is false.
It is used together with the if statement.

sections.heading: Syntax
Example
Explanation
paragraphs: The variable time is compared with 18.
Since time is 20, the condition is false and the else block runs.
If time were less than 18, the program would print "Good day" instead.

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: What is the purpose of the else statement in C?
list: To execute a block of code if the if condition is true
To execute a block of code if the if condition is false

sections.heading: The else if Statement
paragraphs: The else if statement is used to specify a new condition if the first if condition is false.
It is used between an if statement and an else statement.

sections.heading: Syntax
Example
Explanation
paragraphs: The value of time is first checked against 10.
Since 22 is greater than 10, the first condition is false.
The next condition (time < 20) is also false.
Because both conditions fail, the else block runs and prints "Good evening".
If time were 14, the program would print "Good day".

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: What is the purpose of the else if statement in C?
list: To check a new condition if the first if condition is true
To specify a new condition if the first if condition is false

sections.heading: The Ternary Operator
paragraphs: The ternary operator is a shorthand way of writing an if...else statement.
It is called a ternary operator because it takes three operands: a condition, an expression to execute if the condition is true, and an expression to execute if the condition is false.

sections.heading: Syntax
sections.example: variable = (condition) ? expressionTrue : expressionFalse;

sections.heading: Traditional If...Else
Using Ternary Operator
sections.example:
int time = 20;
(time < 18) ? printf("Good day.") : printf("Good evening.");

sections.heading: Explanation
paragraphs: The condition (time < 18) is evaluated first.
If the condition is true, the first expression runs.
If the condition is false, the second expression runs.
Both versions produce the same output, but the ternary operator uses fewer lines.

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: What is the purpose of the ternary operator in C?
list: To provide a shorthand way of writing an if...else statement

sections.heading: Nested if Statements
paragraphs: You can also use if statements inside another if statement. This is called a nested if statement.
Nested if statements are useful when you need to check multiple conditions that depend on each other.

sections.heading: Syntax
Basic Example
paragraphs: First, the program checks if x is greater than 10.
If true, it then checks if y is greater than 20.

sections.heading: Output
sections.example:
x is greater than 10
y is also greater than 20

sections.heading: Real-Life Example
paragraphs: Nested if statements are useful when multiple conditions depend on each other.
For example, checking age first, then checking citizenship.

sections.heading: Notes
list: You can nest as many if statements as needed.
Avoid too much nesting as it can make code hard to read.
Nested if is often used with else and else if for complex decisions.

switch.title: C Switch Statement
paragraphs: Instead of writing many if...else statements, you can use the switch statement.
The switch statement selects one of many code blocks to be executed.
working: The switch expression is evaluated once.
The value of the expression is compared with each case.
If a match is found, the corresponding code block is executed.
The break statement stops further case testing.
The default block runs if no case matches (optional).

sections.heading: Weekday Example
paragraphs: Uses a number to print the corresponding weekday.

sections.heading: The break Keyword
paragraphs: The break statement stops execution inside the switch block.
It prevents the program from executing other case blocks.
It also saves execution time by skipping unnecessary comparisons.

sections.heading: The default Keyword
paragraphs: The default keyword runs if none of the cases match.
It must appear last and does not require a break.

while-loop.title: C While Loop
intro: Loops can execute a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.
Loops are handy because they save time, reduce errors, and make code more readable.
while-loop.definition: The while loop repeats a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.

notes: Always update the variable used in the condition (like i++) to avoid infinite loops.
If the condition is false at the start, the loop body will not execute.
The do...while loop always runs at least once before checking the condition.

do-while-loop.title: C Do/While Loop
intro: The do/while loop is a variant of the while loop.
It executes the code block once before checking the condition, and then repeats while the condition is true.
do-while-loop.definition: The do/while loop always runs at least once, even if the condition is false at the start.

examples.title: Basic Do/While Loop

notes: The loop body runs once before the condition is checked.
Always update the condition variable to avoid infinite loops.
Useful when an action must happen at least once, such as user input.

Expression 3 runs after each loop iteration.

The continue statement skips the current iteration and moves to the next one.

intro: Arrays are used to store multiple values in a single variable.
All elements in an array must be of the same data type.
concepts: You cannot change the size of an array after creation.
All values must be of the same data type.

examples.title: Create an Array
examples.code: int myNumbers[] = {25, 50, 75, 100};

examples.title: Access Array Element
examples.code:
int myNumbers[] = {25, 50, 75, 100};
printf("%d", myNumbers[0]);

examples.title: Change Array Element
Set Array Size First

notes: Indexes begin from 0.
Arrays store fixed-size data.
Mixing data types can cause truncation or errors.

exercise.question: What is the correct syntax to declare an array of integers with values 25, 50, 75, and 100?

array_size.title: C Array Size
intro: You can use the sizeof operator to get the memory size of an array.
sizeof returns the total number of bytes used by the array.
concepts: sizeof(array) returns the total size in bytes.
int usually takes 4 bytes, so 5 integers take 20 bytes.
To get the number of elements, divide total size by size of one element.

examples.title: Get Array Memory Size
examples.code:
int myNumbers[] = {10, 25, 50, 75, 100};
printf("%zu", sizeof(myNumbers));

examples.title: Get Number of Elements
Works for Any Type

notes: sizeof returns bytes, not element count.
Use sizeof(array) / sizeof(array[0]) to get total elements.
This formula works for all data types.

array_loop.title: C Array Loop
intro: You can use a loop to go through each element of an array.
Using a fixed number in the loop condition is not flexible.
concepts: A for loop can iterate through array elements using indexes.
Hardcoding the array length is not recommended.
Using sizeof makes the loop work for any array size.

examples.title: Loop with Fixed Size (Not Recommended)
Flexible Loop Using sizeof

notes: Never hardcode the array size in loops.
Always use sizeof(array) / sizeof(array[0]).
This method adapts automatically to array size.

array_real_life_examples.title: C Arrays - Real-Life Examples
intro: Arrays are widely used in real programs to store and process groups of values.
They allow us to calculate results like averages, minimum values, and filtered lists.
concepts: Looping through arrays to process all values.
Using sizeof to get the number of elements.
Using conditions like if, break, and continue while looping.

examples.title: Calculate Average Age
Find the Lowest Age
Skip Negatives and Stop at Zero

notes: Always calculate array length using sizeof.
Use loops to process each element.
break stops the loop, continue skips the current iteration.

multidimensional_arrays.title: C Multidimensional Arrays
intro: A multidimensional array is an array of arrays.
It is used to store data in rows and columns, like tables or matrices.
The most common type is the two-dimensional (2D) array.

loop_example.title: Loop Through a 2D Array

notes: Array indexes always start from 0.
Each dimension needs its own loop.
Use nested loops for multi-dimensional arrays.

instructions: Declare an int array named numbers with 5 elements
Print the first element using printf
Print the last element using printf

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: Strings are used for storing text/characters.
Unlike many other languages, C does not have a String type. Instead, you use char arrays.
Example: char greetings[] = "Hello World!";
sections.example:
char greetings[] = "Hello World!";
printf("%s", greetings);

sections.heading: Access Strings
paragraphs: Strings are arrays, so you can access characters using indexes.
Use %c to print a single character.
sections.example:
char greetings[] = "Hello World!";
printf("%c", greetings[0]);

sections.heading: Modify Strings
paragraphs: You can change characters using indexes and single quotes.

sections.heading: Loop Through a String
paragraphs: Use loops to iterate through characters.
Always prefer sizeof formula.

sections.heading: Another Way to Create Strings
paragraphs: You can also define strings as character arrays with a null terminator.
The \0 marks the end of the string.
sections.example:
char greetings[] = {'H','e','l','l','o',' ','W','o','r','l','d','!','\0'};
printf("%s", greetings);

sections.heading: Special Characters
sections.example: char txt[] = "We are the so-called \"Vikings\" from the north.";

sections.heading: String Functions
paragraphs: To use string functions, include <string.h>.
Common functions: strlen, strcat, strcpy, strcmp.

challenge.title: Create a Greeting Message

sections.heading: Introduction
paragraphs: printf() is used to output values in C.
To get user input, we use the scanf() function.

sections.heading: Single Number Input
notes: scanf takes a format specifier and a variable address.
The & operator stores the memory address.

sections.heading: Multiple Inputs
String Input Using scanf
notes: Do not use & for strings in scanf.
scanf stops reading at whitespace.

sections.heading: String Input Using fgets
notes: Use fgets for multi-word input.
It reads until a newline is found.

sections.question: Which function is used to get user input in C?

sections.heading: Creating Pointers
paragraphs: You can get the memory address of a variable using the & reference operator.
A pointer is a variable that stores the memory address of another variable.
Pointer variables are created using the * operator and must match the data type they point to.

sections.heading: Example Explained
list: ptr is a pointer to an int variable.
The & operator stores the memory address of myAge.
ptr now holds the address of myAge.

sections.heading: Dereference Operator
paragraphs: You can access the value of the variable a pointer points to by using the * operator.
This is called dereferencing.

sections.heading: Pointer Declaration Notes
notes: In declaration, * creates a pointer.
In usage, * dereferences the pointer.

sections.heading: Why Pointers Are Important
paragraphs: Pointers allow direct memory manipulation.
They improve performance and reduce code.
They are essential for data structures, files, and memory management.
They must be used carefully to avoid memory corruption.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: How do you declare a pointer to an int variable?

sections.heading: Pointer Arithmetic
paragraphs: Pointer arithmetic means changing the value of a pointer to make it point to a different element in memory.
Array elements are stored next to each other in memory. Adding 1 to a pointer moves it to the next element.

sections.heading: Increment and Decrement
paragraphs: Pointers can be moved using ++, --, += and -= operators.

sections.heading: Pointer Subtraction
paragraphs: Subtracting two pointers gives the number of elements between them.
Both pointers must point inside the same array.

sections.heading: Pointer Arithmetic Depends on Type
paragraphs: Pointer movement depends on the data type it points to.
int* moves 4 bytes, char* moves 1 byte.

sections.heading: Looping with Pointers
paragraphs: You can loop through an array by moving the pointer itself.

sections.heading: Pointer to Pointer
paragraphs: A pointer to pointer stores the address of another pointer.
It adds another level of indirection.

sections.heading: Change Value Using Pointer to Pointer
Pointer Code Challenge

instructions: Declare pointer ptr that points to x
Print value of x using ptr

sections.heading: What is a Function?
paragraphs: A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called.
You can pass data into a function using parameters.
Functions are used to reuse code: define once, use many times.

sections.heading: Predefined Functions
paragraphs: main() is a function used to execute the program.
printf() is a function used to print output.

sections.heading: Create a Function
paragraphs: To create a function, specify the name followed by () and {}.
void means the function does not return a value.

sections.heading: Call a Function
paragraphs: Functions are not executed until they are called.
To call a function, write its name followed by ();

sections.heading: Calling a Function Multiple Times
Calculate the Sum of Numbers
paragraphs: Functions can contain logic and calculations.
This example shows a function that calculates a sum.

sections.heading: Exercise
sections.question: What does the keyword void indicate when used with a function in C?
options: The function can only be called once
The function does not return a value
The function can accept any type of parameter
sections.answer: The function does not return a value

sections.heading: Parameters and Arguments
paragraphs: Information can be passed to functions as parameters.
Parameters act as variables inside the function.
When a function is called, the passed values are called arguments.

sections.heading: Single Parameter Example
Multiple Parameters
Using Parameters for Calculation
Notes on Parameters
paragraphs: The number of arguments must match the number of parameters.
Arguments must be passed in the same order as parameters.

sections.heading: Pass Arrays as Parameters
Return Values
paragraphs: Use a data type instead of void if the function should return a value.
Use the return keyword inside the function.

sections.heading: Return with Two Parameters
Storing Multiple Results in Array
Real-Life Example: Fahrenheit to Celsius
Scope
paragraphs: Variables are only accessible inside the region they are created.
This region is called the variable scope.
Scope controls where a variable can be used in a program.

sections.heading: Local Scope
paragraphs: A variable created inside a function belongs to the local scope.
It can only be used inside that function.

sections.heading: Local Scope Error Example
paragraphs: Local variables cannot be accessed outside their function.

sections.heading: Global Scope
paragraphs: A variable created outside any function is a global variable.
Global variables can be accessed from any function.

sections.heading: Same Name in Local and Global Scope
paragraphs: C treats local and global variables with the same name as separate variables.
The local variable overrides the global one inside the function.

sections.heading: Modifying Global Variables
paragraphs: Global variables can be modified from any function.
This can make programs harder to debug and maintain.

sections.heading: Conclusion
paragraphs: Use local variables whenever possible.
Avoid using global variables unless necessary.
Good scoping makes code easier to understand and maintain.

sections.heading: Function Declaration and Definition
paragraphs: A function in C consists of two parts: declaration and definition.
Declaration includes the function name, return type, and parameters.
Definition contains the actual body of the function.

sections.heading: Separating Declaration and Definition
paragraphs: For better organization and optimization, declarations are usually written before main().
Definitions are written after main().

sections.heading: Functions with Parameters
paragraphs: When a function uses parameters, it is good practice to separate declaration and definition.

sections.heading: Functions Calling Other Functions
paragraphs: Functions can call other functions if they are declared first.
This allows modular and reusable code.

Math Functions
paragraphs: There is also a list of math functions available, that allows you to perform mathematical tasks on numbers.
To use them, you must include the math.h header file in your program:
sections.example: #include <math.h>

sections.heading: Square Root
paragraphs: To find the square root of a number, use the sqrt() function:
sections.example: printf("%f", sqrt(16));

sections.heading: Round a Number
paragraphs: The ceil() function rounds a number upwards to its nearest integer.
The floor() function rounds a number downwards to its nearest integer.
sections.example:
printf("%f", ceil(1.4));
printf("%f", floor(1.4));

sections.heading: Power
paragraphs: The pow() function returns the value of x to the power of y (xʸ):
sections.example: printf("%f", pow(4, 3));

sections.heading: Reference
paragraphs: For a complete reference of math functions, go to the C <math.h> Library Reference.

sections.heading: Inline Function
paragraphs: You might sometimes see the inline keyword used in other people's functions.
An inline function is a small function that asks the compiler to insert its code directly where it is called, instead of jumping to it.
This can make short, frequently used functions a little faster, because it removes the small delay of a normal function call.

sections.heading: Regular Function vs Inline Function
paragraphs: Both functions work the same way. The only difference is that the inline version suggests to the compiler to copy the function's code directly where it is used.

sections.heading: Inline Function Example
paragraphs: Here is a simple example that uses an inline function:

sections.heading: When Not to Use Inline
paragraphs: Inline functions are best for small, simple functions. Avoid using them for:
Large functions
Recursive functions
Functions that are rarely called
Too many inline functions can make your program slower and larger, a problem known as code bloat.

sections.heading: Inline vs Regular Function
paragraphs: Regular function: Code jumps to the function each time it's called.
Inline function: Code is inserted directly where it's called.
Regular function: Slightly slower.
Inline function: Slightly faster.
Regular function: Good for large functions.
Inline function: Good for small functions.

sections.heading: Summary
paragraphs: Inline functions are defined with the inline keyword.
They can make small, often-used functions faster.
The compiler decides whether to inline a function or not.
Mostly used for short, simple functions.

sections.heading: Recursion
paragraphs: Recursion is the technique of making a function call itself.
This technique provides a way to break complicated problems down into simple problems which are easier to solve.
Recursion may be a bit difficult to understand. The best way to figure out how it works is to experiment with it.

sections.heading: Recursion Example: Sum of Numbers
paragraphs: Use recursion to add all numbers from 1 to 10.

sections.heading: Example Explained
paragraphs: When the sum() function is called, it adds parameter k to the sum of all numbers smaller than k.
When k becomes 0, the function returns 0 and stops calling itself.

sections.heading: Important Note
paragraphs: The developer should be very careful with recursion.
It is easy to write a function which never terminates or uses too much memory.
When written correctly, recursion can be an efficient and elegant solution.

paragraphs: Use recursion to count down from 5.

sections.heading: Factorial with Recursion
paragraphs: This example calculates the factorial of 5 using recursion.

sections.heading: Factorial Explanation
paragraphs: Factorial means multiplying a number by every number below it, down to 1.
By definition, 0! is also 1.

sections.heading: Function Pointer
paragraphs: A function pointer is like a normal pointer, but instead of pointing to a variable, it points to a function.
It stores the address of a function and allows you to call that function using the pointer.
Function pointers let you decide which function to run at runtime or pass functions as arguments.

sections.heading: Declaring a Function Pointer
paragraphs: General syntax:
returnType (*pointerName)(parameterType1, parameterType2, ...);
Example:
int (*ptr)(int, int);

sections.heading: Assigning and Calling a Function
paragraphs: Assigning:
ptr = add;
ptr = &add;
Calling:

Passing a Function as Argument (Callback)
paragraphs: Function pointers can be passed to other functions. This is called a callback.
The receiving function can call it back when needed.

sections.heading: Function Pointer Array
paragraphs: You can store multiple function pointers in an array.

sections.heading: Calculator Using Function Pointer Array

paragraphs: A callback function is a function passed as an argument to another function.
It allows flexible and reusable program logic.
In C, callbacks are implemented using function pointers.

Summary
paragraphs: A function pointer stores the address of a function.
Callbacks allow functions to be passed and executed later.
Function pointer arrays allow dynamic behavior.

c_create_files.title: C Files - Create Files
paragraphs: In C, you can create, open, read, and write to files by declaring a pointer of type FILE and using the fopen() function.
FILE is a data type used for file handling. We create a pointer variable (fptr) to work with files.

sections.heading: Opening a File
paragraphs: To open a file, use the fopen() function:
FILE *fptr;
fptr = fopen(filename, mode);

sections.heading: fopen() Parameters
list: filename - The name of the file, e.g., filename.txt
mode - A character that decides how the file is opened
w - Write mode (creates file if not exists)

sections.heading: Create a File
paragraphs: To create a file, use the w mode. If the file does not exist, it will be created.

sections.heading: Create File in a Folder
paragraphs: You can create a file in a specific folder using an absolute path.
sections.example: fptr = fopen("C:\\directoryname\\filename.txt", "w");

sections.heading: Closing a File
paragraphs: Always close a file using fclose().
This ensures data is saved, memory is cleaned, and other programs can use the file.
sections.example: fclose(fptr);

sections.heading: Why Close Files?
list: Allows other programs to access the file

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: Which function can be used to open a file in C?

c_write_files.title: C Files - Write To Files
paragraphs: The w mode opens a file for writing and allows you to insert content into it.
To write to a file, use the fprintf() function with the file pointer and the text you want to store.

sections.heading: Write to a File
paragraphs: Using w mode, you can write text into a file.
If the file already exists, its content will be deleted before writing new data.

sections.heading: Overwriting Existing Content
paragraphs: Writing to a file that already exists using w mode will erase the old content.
Only the new text will remain in the file.
sections.example: fprintf(fptr, "Hello World!");

sections.heading: Append Content to a File
paragraphs: To add new content without deleting the existing data, use the a mode.
The a mode appends text at the end of the file.

sections.heading: Notes
list: The w mode deletes existing file content before writing.
The a mode keeps existing content and adds new text.
Both w and a modes will create a file if it does not exist.

c_read_files.title: C Files - Read Files
paragraphs: To read from a file in C, you must open it using the r mode with the fopen() function.
Reading a file requires storing its content into a character array using fgets().

sections.heading: Open a File for Reading
paragraphs: Use the r mode to open a file for reading.
If the file does not exist, fopen() will return NULL.

sections.heading: Store File Content
paragraphs: Create a character array large enough to store file data.
This example creates a string that can hold up to 100 characters.
sections.example: char myString[100];

sections.heading: Read a Single Line
paragraphs: Use fgets() to read one line from the file.
It reads only the first line by default.
sections.example: fgets(myString, 100, fptr);

sections.heading: Read and Print a File
paragraphs: This example reads the first line from the file and prints it.

sections.heading: Read All Lines Using a Loop
paragraphs: To read the entire file, use fgets() inside a while loop.

sections.heading: Good Practice: Check for NULL
paragraphs: If the file does not exist, fopen() returns NULL.
Always check before reading the file.

sections.heading: Safe Read Example
paragraphs: This example checks if the file exists before reading it.

sections.heading: Notes
list: The r mode is used to read from a file.
fgets() reads one line at a time.
Always check for NULL when opening files.
Use a loop to read the full file.
